title: Synthesis of Titanium Carbide Nanoparticles by Magnesiotermic Method
content: Titanium carbide (TiC) is a material that has garnered significant attention due to its high melting point (3338 K), rendering it resistant to wear, thus finding applications in aerospace materials [1]. For the mentioned applications, there is interest in producing TiC powders with a fine particle size and narrow distribution. Where the crystallization shape and exposed facets of TiC particles influences its physical and chemical properties [2]. Various methods are proposed for producing TiC powder, such as the carbo-thermal process, self-sustained reactive sintering, microwave, and electrospinning [3]. The motivation of this work is to synthesize TiC employing turbostratic carbon as a carbon source and metallic titanium powder. From Alfa Aesar (44 µm), 0.80 g of 99.5% titanium powder and 0.20 g of turbostratic carbon were used. The powders were homogenized in an agate mortar for 30 minutes, forming a pellet by pressing at 218 MPa [4]. The sample was covered with 3 g of metallic magnesium for ignition. This stage was carried out in a CO2 atmosphere to prevent reaction with atmospheric oxygen. Additionally, the synthesis reaction produces magnesium oxide as a byproduct. Hence, it is necessary to wash the powders for approximately 3 h at room temperature with constant agitation using hydrochloric acid [5]. Structural characterization was performed using a Panalytical X'pert PRO diffractometer operated at 40 kV and 30 mA with CuKα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was utilized to evaluate the morphology. The microstructures of the TiC were characterized using bright-field mode in a transmission electron microscope (TEM), model JEOL JEM2200FS.
